body:
Not really a bug, except for **+h**
The -S output is like this

```
grdinterpolate evi_cube.nc -S580740/4418042+hNOTHING
> Location 580740,4.41804e+06
580740  4418042 0.435693833952  1601406069
580740  4418042 0.454324448886  1601578341
580740  4418042 0.449739509291  1601838161
580740  4418042 0.490814018364  1602010369
...
```
First the **+h** is ignored but the worst are the first two columns that are completely irrelevant and should not be printed.
Also, I think the 3rth and 4rth columns should be swapped as we normally want *x,y* and not *y,x*.

Finally, it would be nice if the segment header contained the *z_unit* attribute. This would be particularly useful when the vertical axis is time and *z_unit* carries the info about the time system.

comments_content.body: Could you help my cause by posting a small cube as an example to look at?

Trying this on our cube.nc:

```
gmt grdinterpolate cube.nc -S4.5/4+hdummy
> Location 4.5,4
4.5	4	18	1
4.5	4	19.8000002503	2
4.5	4	21.6000005007	3
4.5	4	25.1999999285	5
```

I.e., x and y are given first, not y and x, but I see z is 4th and node-value is 3rd.  These need to be flipped.  That what you meant?

```
gmt grdinterpolate cube.nc -S4.5/4+hdummy -o2,1
> Location 18,4
1	4
2	4
3	4
5	4

```

No crash.  So please post an example that crashes, with data. Note how the Location message is wrong due to **-o** though...

Yes flip 3 , 4 and remove 1,2. They are useless. Same info is in the header. 

Sent from my iDedo

> No dia 24/10/2021, às 20:44, Paul Wessel ***@***.***> escreveu:
> 
> ﻿
> Trying this on our cube.nc:
> 
> gmt grdinterpolate cube.nc -S4.5/4+hdummy
> > Location 4.5,4
> 4.5	4	18	1
> 4.5	4	19.8000002503	2
> 4.5	4	21.6000005007	3
> 4.5	4	25.1999999285	5
> I.e., x and y are given first, not y and x, but I see z is 4th and node-value is 3rd. These need to be flipped. That what you meant?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android.

Not sure about that.  I prefer we use -o to exclude x,y rather than not having the option of getting them. Remember -S can take a table instead of a fixed point and I do want to preserve x,y.  Output should be x,y,z,value and -o can be used to change that.

Why do we want the same point repeated N times?

Sent from my iDedo

> No dia 24/10/2021, às 21:05, Paul Wessel ***@***.***> escreveu:
> 
> ﻿
> Not sure about that. I prefer we use -o to exclude x,y rather than not having the option of getting them. Remember -S can take a table instead of a fixed point and I do want to preserve x,y. Output should be x,y,z,value and -o can be used to change that.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android.

I can imagine someone doing various statistics and want to keep the (x,y)
point for various values in their workflow.  It is _way_ harder to extract
that from the string in the header and add to the records than to just use
-o2:
So rather do that than cripple the output and making it very difficult to
recover.
The -o2: works now (here) will update the bug fixes after more testing.

Paul Wessel, Professor
Dept. of Earth Sciences
SOEST, U of Hawaii at Manoa

wrote:

Why do we want the same point repeated N times?

I would say they are supposed to know those points because they entered it in first place via the program options instead of forcing all the others to remove the 2 columns, but not that important.

They do know the coordinates but since each x,y coordinate in the users -Sdatafile ends up being replicated for each output record produced by -S down the cube, it is just not easy to replicate those values separately.  At least not compared to the work of adding -o2:.

Well, there was still the issue

> Finally, it would be nice if the segment header contained the z_unit attribute. This would be particularly useful when the vertical axis is time and z_unit carries the info about the time system.
Sorry, missed that.  So in the segment header(s) from -S output you wish to add a label -L<unit>?

Well, yes a label may be the best way. My Julia stack function saves the vertical time units as
```
			v = GMT.yeardecimal.(v);			z_unit = "Decimal year"
		elseif (startswith(_z_unit, "mil"))
			v = Dates.datetime2epochms.(v);	z_unit = "Milliseconds since 0000-01-01T00:00:00"
		elseif (_z_unit == "seconds")
			v = Dates.datetime2epochms.(v) / 1000.;	z_unit = "Seconds since 0000-01-01T00:00:00"
		elseif (_z_unit == "" || _z_unit == "unix")
			v = Dates.datetime2unix.(v);			z_unit = "Seconds since 1970-01-01T00:00:00"
		elseif (_z_unit == "rata")
			v = Dates.datetime2rata.(v);			z_unit = "Days since 0000-12-31T00:00:00"
		elseif (_z_unit == "date" || _zunit == "datetime")
			v = string.(v);					z_unit = "ISO Date Time"
```
and I seem to remember having seen similar descriptions in other netcdf files. The idea is that looking at this type of info, that may as well be pressure, altitude, etc, one may decide how to make the (x,y) plots from point/track interpolations.

BTW, I find the [RATA DIE](https://docs.generic-mapping-tools.org/dev/gmt.conf.html#term-TIME_SYSTEM) description very confusing. When I see ``RATA | 0000-12-31T00:00:00`` I read *one day before the end of year*. That is, end of day 364, beginning of day 365, but this is actually the end of day 365.

Well, you gotta deal with @WalterHFSmith on the RATA stuff.
I will see what I can do with the unit business.  It would be helpful if you could open a new issue to track this thing (the unit).

Friends, not sure what the issue is here. If we are generating 0000-12-31T00:00:00 is that due to a bug, or are we correctly calculating midnight at the start of December 31 in Proleptic Gregorian Year Zero ?
The term "rata die" comes from a book on Calendrical Calculations, from which I built the first version of our routines to convert between time elapsed since some epoch and calendarTclock absolute times.
I used the original edition of that book, but I see there is a more recent edition. I don't know what the newer addition may have added/changed.

I have commented.




> On Oct 25, 2021, at 4:02 PM, Paul Wessel ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> 
> Well, you gotta deal with @WalterHFSmith on the RATA stuff.
> I will see what I can do with the unit business. It would be helpful if you could open a new issue to track this thing (the unit).
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS or Android. 
>

Hi Walter, no bug. It's just that this notation does not make sense to me (but apparently it should be only me).
Some Julia examples
```
julia> DateTime(0, 12, 31)
0000-12-31T00:00:00
```
So this is exactly the same as the RATA Die in GMT. The problem as I said is that when I read that date I see **first second of day 31 of December** and not **last second of that day** as is also implied by Julia time
```
julia> Dates.value(DateTime(0, 12, 31))
0
```
Other examples:
```
julia> DateTime(1, 1, 1)
0001-01-01T00:00:00
```
Again, I read this as **first second of day January first year 1** and next seams to confirm it
```
julia> DateTime(1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0)
0001-01-01T01:00:00
```
**hour 1 of that day**
but let's see the (milliseconds) of those DateTimes

```
julia> Dates.value(DateTime(1, 1, 1))
86400000
```
Ah, a full day in milliseconds, so ``0001-01-01T00:00:00`` means the end of day, not the beginning.

and

```
julia> Dates.value(DateTime(1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0))
90000000
```
So first hour of first day is already in second day.

I know this is in Julia but the ``DateTime(0, 12, 31)  0000-12-31T00:00:00`` is exactly the same as we see in the RATA Die in GMT and afaik they behave the same. So, it works but I don't understand this notation.

Dear Joaquim,
I am not sure I understand but I am glad Julia is giving the same calculations. Is it simply a question of the floor/ceiling problem? That is, 00:00:01 today is clearly "inside" time today, and 23:59:59 is also, but is 00:00:00 the 86400th second in today, or the 0th second in today? There has to be a convention about this; it cannot be both. Are you saying that 0001-01-01T00:00:00 should give the beginning of seconds on the first day of the proleptic Gregorian year system?
Maybe it makes more sense to say this: if we use the proleptic Gregorian year system as our Epoch for the Origin of Time, and we then convert a relative time of 0 to YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss format, what do we get?
W

title: grdinterolate -S output
